awd_titl_txt: Targeted Infusion Project: Infusing an Honors Curriculum to Enrich the Undergraduate Research Experience in Psychological Sciences
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue science, technology, engineering or mathematics (STEM) graduate programs and/or careers. The project at Winston-Salem State University (WSSU) seeks to enhance the quality and experience of underrepresented undergraduate students in the psychology department with the goal of increasing the number of students prepared for research careers.  The project takes the novel approach of integrating the psychology curriculum with natural science and infusing it with cultural neuroscience, an emerging interdisciplinary field.  The activities and strategies are evidence-based.  

This project has the objectives to: establish an honors curriculum within the department; enhance the curricular offerings within the psychology program at WSSU by improving the biological/cognitive foundation area; and modernize and upgrade the instructional and research equipment used by students and faculty.  The project is designed to keep students engaged in scientific discovery, promote interactions between students and faculty, and expose students to current and emerging technology.  Demonstrating and evaluating a pathway for psychology majors to the field of cognitive science and STEM research preparation could serve as a model to other programs.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

inst.inst_street_address: 601 S MARTIN LUTHER KING JR DR

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this target infusion project were to enhance the quality and experience of historically marginalized undergraduate students in the Department of Psychological Sciences (DPS) at Winston-Salem State University (WSSU).  We employed a three-pronged approach to enhance the learning and training environment for students in the DPS. This infusion fostered the development of a science identity, which facilitates persistence and increased academic performance. Additionally, this infusion was designed to keep the students engaged in scientific discovery, provide an avenue for focused student-faculty interaction, and expose students to current and emerging technology. Meeting these goals and objectives created a paradigm shift within the DPS and improved the preparation and success of our students entering Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) graduate programs and/or professional fields.

Psychology has and continues to be, an extremely popular major with students. Although Psychology is often excluded from the list of core STEM disciplines responsible for scientific and technological progress, psychological knowledge is essential to scientific and technological innovation. Though frequently overlooked and undervalued as a STEM discipline, psychological knowledge has been reported to facilitate students’ math and science learning; it also enhances analytical skills, scientific literacy, and problem-solving processes. Thus, having DPS students participate in a plethora of activities in the discipline is designed to enhance their science identity and further enhance their appreciation for the important role psychology plays in not only STEM but their everyday lives.  

Fostering a science identity to facilitate persistence among historically marginalized students in psychology, and other STEM disciplines is critical. We used a model developed by Carlone and Johnson which includes three intersecting components: competence, performance, and recognition. There is significant evidence supporting the argument that persistence in STEM education not only requires mastery of scientific and technical skills but also entails a social psychological process by which students begin to see science as a salient part of their identity. This project employed a variety of evidence-based instructional practices to enhance student learning and outcomes. These strategies focused on integrating the best available research on teaching techniques with the social and cultural context of our students, institution, and surrounding communities. The major activities undertaken during this project were designed to create a supportive culture that expanded students’ knowledge, comprehension, and experience with science and research. These activities included: 1) creating an honors curriculum; 2) a Psychological Sciences Colloquium Series; 3) a summer Cultural Neuroscience Institute; 4) Mentored research experiences; and 5) an Academic Enhancement Program, which included regular meetings with a Writing Coach.

One of the most impactful parts of this project was the introduction to, and infusion of, cultural neuroscience (CN) into the DPS. Cultural neuroscience is an interdisciplinary field that investigates the relationship between culture (e.g., value and belief systems and practices shared by groups) and human brain functions. Investigating CN created research opportunities that included culture as a significant variable. Increasing students’ preparedness and success in STEM research careers promote social justice, which is another initiative of WSSU. Via our students’ and faculty’s research collaborations with other scientists on campus, statewide, and internationally, important breakthroughs in the developing field of CN may be achieved. 

The National Academy of Science stresses the importance of increasing the participation of students of color to ensure the scientific, technological, and economic development in the U.S. Attracting more African Americans in STEM disciplines is a national priority; however, trends for their persistence have not been promising. This project was able to incorporate multiple components intended to foster a science identity for African American psychology students, strengthen their academic skills, and create a culture of science and research to increase their interest, representation, and persistence in STEM fields. These strategies included more focused opportunities for research, mentoring, scholarly exchange, and professional development. An overview of significant outcomes of the project include:

  • 8 of 10 students (80%) completed the honors curriculum, an honors thesis, and graduated with honors in psychology.
    • 100% of students had an accepted abstract and presented their research at a professional conference
    • 75% of the students were accepted into a STEM graduate program
  • 10 undergraduate students (5 juniors/5 seniors) participated in the one-year, intense Academic Enhancement Program.
    • All five of the seniors received GRE prep courses and writing assistance.
    • Four of the five (80%) seniors were accepted into graduate school.
  • 15 students, who had no previous research experience, were mentored by faculty members and completed intensive methodological, statistical, and research training.
  • 25 undergraduate students completed the intensive summer Cultural Neuroscience Institute, with 2 students continuing research in the field
  • More than 400 different students participated in Psychological Sciences Colloquium Series.

Via our completed targeted infusion, we were able to inspire more undergraduate students to pursue science and research careers and assist students to prepare for STEM graduate programs.

 


Last Modified: 09/30/2021
Modified by: Denise Nation
